Situation1: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: A weekly study slot is planned, and lessons could be shifted without losing continuity.
Story: I sit at my desk, headset snug, the hum of the call center in my ears. My shift as a telemarketer is usually straightforward—most callers are polite, and the script covers nearly every question. Today, though, my mind drifts to the lesson I promised my kids tonight. We’re supposed to talk about the story of Ruth, about kindness and loyalty, values I want them to carry. My supervisor pings me: “Can you stay late? We’re short-staffed.” I glance at the clock. If I agree, I’ll miss our study slot. I could reschedule, but I know how much the kids look forward to our time together, how important it is to pass on our traditions. At the same time, I feel the pressure to be a team player at work, to handle every call with patience and professionalism. My stomach knots as I weigh the expectations—be the reliable employee, be the devoted parent and teacher. The phone rings again, and I’m caught between two worlds, unsure which one I’ll have to let down.
